intro: Peucedanum utriculatum, commonly known as the bladder senna, is a flowering plant native to Central Asia and parts of Europe. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its fruit is a dry, two-lobed capsule that contains several small, oval seeds. Peucedanum utriculatum is often found in rocky or arid environments and is adapted to survive in harsh conditions.
